name: ACP
summary: The deliberately simple alternative to A2A. REST-native, no SDK required — works with curl. Multimodal (text, images, audio, video) via MIME types. ACP's design philosophy is anti-Kafka: reduce complexity, not add it. The risk is the Bartleby problem in reverse — it might be TOO simple for the complexity of real multi-agent systems, leading participants to bolt on complexity until ACP loses its simplicity advantage.

feedbackLoop.note: Standard HTTP status codes. Clear request/response. Errors are visible.

edgeCases.note: Deliberately minimal. REST verbs (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) handle all cases.

ambiguity.note: HTTP semantics are well-understood. No novel abstractions to misinterpret.

redundancy.note: Directly competes with A2A for the agent-to-agent communication space. Google's momentum is overwhelming.

nesting.note: Flat REST calls. No recursive protocol chains.

exitCost.note: No SDK dependency. Standard HTTP. Trivial to switch away from.

identityPenetration.note: No tribal identity. IBM/BeeAI branding is understated.

agencyPreservation.note: Maximum agency — any HTTP client works. No framework lock-in.

controlInvisibility.note: REST is the most visible, well-understood protocol pattern in software. Nothing hidden.

crisisMindset.note: No urgency narrative. Positioned as pragmatic alternative, not revolutionary necessity.
